content.description:
This boulder is to the left of the downclimb. I'm not sure of the name, but this name seems to be used.

I found this boulder in the middle of the pipe-side of the pipeline boulder. The most obvious thing to do was to use the arete with my right hand, and then work up to a slick shelf at 8-9 feet. From there, you can cheat right (makes it about v4), or you can boldly go up and left (which could be why this is called v6 sometimes). I don't know. It's a bit spooky going up and left, but the rock is good, and the moves are great.

It's also possible that "Tim's" line is further to the left of what I climbed today. Let me know, and I'll change the name and grade to whatever it is supposed to be.
content.protection: would be great to have more pads than i had, but 1 big and 1 regular worked for me
content.location: There is a pale white arete in the middle of the pipe-side of the pipeline boulder. I used that for my right hand, and then you can decide whether to finish left or right from the slick shelf.

content.description: A bit crumbly, but great techy moves on non-holds. Unusually good landing for this boulder, with nice fat logs underneath. Good stuff!
content.location: Standing on the pipe, this is the boulder on the right side of the pipe face.

content.description:
Low start to smog arete see

instagram.com/p/CVYPf8CJW8D/
content.location: on arete in between Jack Horner and Ditchwitch

content.description: Start with crimps at head height on both sides of arete
content.location: Arete just left of Ditchwitch

climbs.name: Smells Like Font (AKA Caught in the Spokes)

content.description:
Starts with hands in the jug low and left of the arete with feet on the sloppy shelf. Move up and right along the wonderful granite slopers and pinches to a jug for an easy rock over. See beta image for route intention.

Downclimb is the slab to the right of the top out.
content.location: This boulder problem is a short walk down canyon from the swamp boulder and up canyon from moon rock on the river trail.

content.description:
A classic thin edging problem with a very tall finish. Climbs straight up the slab to the cool flake, then busts right into the River Crack.

A V4 variation starts to the right of this problem, climbing straight up to a bolt stud and then the River Crack.

River Crack V2 starts over left, traversing right on the ledges and then up the tall crack finish. Mostly easy, but one committing move leaving the security of the ledge.
content.protection: Pad for the start...after that you're on your own
content.location: On the east face of the Toprope Boulder. Down canyon from the Bog Boulder.

content.description:
A funky slab problem just to the left of Maisch Slab. Start on opposing sidepulls (obvious left hand) and slick, slanted feet. Make a difficult press into a good foot and get to the jug edge above you. Move up to another good edge rail before making a rad iron cross straight right to huge buckets, finishing on Maisch Slab.

You could finish over left on the lieback jugs on Swamp Monster, but I highly recommend going right. This may have been done, but can’t find any info.
content.location: On the East side of Pipeline Boulder, to the right of the V2 seam and left of Maisch Slab

content.description: From BB: Climb up the right side of the south face of the boulder, starting ofn the right of the terrace landing. Totally Old school.
content.location: Bog Boulder

content.description: Good rails, and a bunch of them makes for a good place to get those fingers woken up.
content.location: pipe-side of pipeline boulder, with some logs underneath.

content.description:
Start with hands low in shot hole pockets and tenuous feet. Reach up right to a good crimp, then figure out how to get feet up to obtain the sharp peanut shell feature with the left. Stand up and grab the excellent lip to finish.

Extra star for aesthetics of this beautiful creekside area.
content.location: Middle of the N face on the block at the W end of the Japanese Garden (on the south bank of the creek just NE of where the pipe crosses the creek)

content.description:
This excellent slab takes on the center of the impressive east face of the Pipeline Boulder. It's only slightly heinous...

Start off a low edge and press into the obvious right hand gaston feature (sort of a hop start). Get stood up on the good foot and contemplate how to reach the bucket that's a few feet above your head.

Enjoy the well earned jug haul to the top.
content.location: East face of Pipeline Boulder. Right up the center, using an obvious vertical rail feature for the right hand.

content.description:
The Tall arete on the southeast corner of Moon Rock.  The holds are all there, still a tad gritty.

Higher than 18 feet if you count the east side fall zone.
content.location: Down climb on the dead trees between the Crippler and Tiny (South/Southwest side)

content.description: Climb the corner / dihedral
content.location: Between Eclipse and Ditchwitch

content.description: From BBStarts in the reeds to the left of [Eclipse]. Climb the face on strange moves. Continuous.
content.location: Slab facing bike trail.

content.description: Start with holds above head height and go straight up the arete (typically done with a knee pad).
content.location: On the arete between Jack Horner and Hike

content.description: Start in the sweet wavy rock. Left hand side pull, right hand gaston and left foot on little nubbin". Hard move to good left hand side pull over the break then up right to the crimpies and sloper lip.
content.location: Boulder immediately west of restoration area

content.description: From the Black Bible - Start sitting with hands on the low shelf at 2.5 feet, then pop straight to the top
content.location: On the north side of the west face on the small rectangular boulder just east of the Bog Boulder

content.description: Fun and straight forward for the grade. Topout can be the crux mentally if you aren't used to manteling slightly highball problems.

Start sitting - paste left foot and set the right on a good edge close to the ground.  Make a big pull off whatever crimps you find best, to a high right hand.  Hike the left foot and move up and left on crimps, to the arete, and then finish up and left.

Not sure if this was the original problem or a variation to the stand.  Regardless, it's great movement.
content.protection: Pads.  A few helpful as the top out is a little high.
content.location: Swamp boulders.  West face.  Left arete is Eclipse - this is the next arete the righ (S)

content.description: The crux is the thin face climbing prior to making the toss to the jug. A few more moves on easier terrain gains the summit.
content.protection: A bouldering pad or two is worthwhile.....
content.location: The problem is located on the South face of the Swamp Boulder. Just right of the shallow left facing dihedral on the South face. Descend via trees on the East side of boulder. The boulder is adjacent to a derelict pavilion.....

content.description: Straight up arete to easy topout
content.location: Notheast arete on large riverside boulder

content.description: Although this problem is completely manufactured by past roadwork or quarrying, the drill scars provide the holds for an outstanding climb. Climb the thirty-foot tall, drill-scared arête on the west face of the boulder, at the edge of the river.

Bell Memorial Arete V5:

Excellent problem. Sit start and work your way up cool edges along the arete to a sloper jug. Mantle through some moss to the top.

Memorial Direct V8:

Sit start off the rock, matched on thin crimps in a seam. Rock over on a high foot and deadpoint to the jug edge.
content.location: On the backside of the Bog Boulder.
